prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA For Dumping my Girlfriend Because she Made Fun of my Sport?
I have dedicated the last 12 years of my life to gymnastics. Specifically trampolining. I have am was a high level national athlete. I have competed at tons of national level competitions and have even competed at quite a few international competitions representing Team Canada. At my peak I was trainning at the trampoline gym 6 times a week, and all my training added up to nearly 30 hours a week on top of high school. Near the end of my career I was even getting funding to continue my sport. Eventually I had to quit because of a head injury, but this was still a huge part of my life and I was immensely proud of it. 

My girlfriend and I met a few months after I stopped competing, and she's heard quite a bit about my sport and always thought it was quite cool. She played volleyball in high school and had played on something rep volleyball teams. Nothing too crazy but I still thought it was pretty cool.

The other day we were discussing sports, and she was telling me how she had wished she played more volleyball and pursued it further. I told her that it was a great feeling to be really good at something and really enjoy it. I told her that it was a lot of work but it felt great to be a top level athlete at a sport. Queue the following conversation:

Her: Yeah, well it's a little different isn't it?

Me: What do you mean?

Her: I mean you were good, but trampolining isn't a real sport.

Me: How do you figure that? I was literally training as much as I went to school and Canada has arguably the most competitive trampolining scene in the world.

Her: Well there's pretty much no one that does that sport. It's not hard to get to a high level, if you played a real sport like soccer you never would've been that good.

I dumped her on the spot. That sport had such a huge impact on who I am today. I dedicated thousands of hours and even ended up getting paid some money to continue training. I was probably within the top 500 athletes worldwide. It felt like she was attacking who I am.

Her friends all said that I'm an asshole for breaking up over something so small. This truly hurt, and it's a sentiment I received from people my whole life. AITA?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the author of the AITA post is in the wrong for breaking up with his girlfriend over her joking that trampolining isn't a real sport. Hmm.

First, I need to consider the situation. The guy dedicated 12 years to trampolining, was a high-level athlete, and took a head injury to quit. That's a lot of dedication. His girlfriend made a comment that trampolining isn't a real sport and that he wouldn't be good at a real sport like soccer. He took it personally, dumped her immediately, and now people are saying he's an asshole for overreacting.

The user thinks the author is in the wrong. So, why would that be the case? Well, relationships require mutual respect. If someone makes a comment that undermines your passion or efforts, that's a problem. But breaking up over a single joke might be overreacting, especially if there's no history of disrespect. On the other hand, if this comment touched a nerve that was a recurring issue, maybe not.

The girlfriend's friends say it's too small a reason. That's a common argument in these situations. But the author felt that the comment was an attack on his identity and dedication. Trampolining being a less mainstream sport might make people dismiss it as not "real," which is something he's faced before. So maybe the hurt was deeper than just a joke.

But here's the thing: the girlfriend made a joke, not a serious attack. People make jokes all the time, and if you take everything personally, it's hard to maintain a relationship. The guy could have addressed the comment, explained why it hurt, and discussed it. Breaking up immediately without talking might not be the healthiest response. Also, considering they met after he stopped competing, maybe she didn't understand the significance of the sport to him.

On the flip side, if this was a pattern where she consistently disrespected his past, then the breakup is justified. But from the post, it seems like this was a one-time joke. So the author might have overreacted. However, if the joke was a deal-breaker because it represented deeper issues of not valuing his achievements, then maybe not. 

In AITA cases, the key factors are respect, communication, and proportionality. The guy felt attacked, which is valid if that's how he perceived it. But acting on a single comment without addressing it first could be seen as the wrong. The girlfriend might have intended it as a joke, not a serious dismissal. So the author's reaction might be too harsh, making him in the wrong. Therefore, answer A.
